top_comment.text:
I honestly thought that this guy was going to bash atheists both I really 
liked what he said. Although I believe there to be no god there's no doubt 
that some people benefit emotionally and in other ways from religion and 
that's great by me. If having a figure of a god makes them happy and fills 
their lives with purpose and hope then I can't say that they shouldn't 
believe. I really wish some christian people could, like me, step on 
someone's shoes and not make unfair assumptions about our lives and values 
and how we feel as atheists.

It really makes me feel bad when I get someone from any religion basically 
pitying me for not believing. They feel as though something in my life is 
missing and that there's no possible way that I'm completely happy without 
god. They are entitled to think what they wish, that is their right and I 
won't stand in the way of it. Although, I do wish people could understand 
that the happiness, hope and fulfilment they get from god I get from 
elsewhere, and that's fine. Some people make me feel as though I am 
purposeless and just wandering around life if I don't follow a religion

The fact that I don't think that my life is ultimately relevant to the 
universe and that I'm not going to be eternal doesn't mean that my life is 
not relevant to myself or that I'm going to live in the limbo after I die. 
It doesn't mean that without the promise of some sort of Eden I'll be a bad 
person. I'm a good person and have values because I understand suffering 
and that's not something I could possibly wish upon anyone. I love every 
single person and understand that everyone is a complex human being that 
can't be labeled as good or bad. I believe we're all made up of chemicals 
and experiences that make us the people we are. And my belief shouldn't 
trouble anyone, the same way other people's beliefs don't trouble me.﻿

top_comment.text:
Speaking from experience (I'm 17 who fell out of religion about 2 years 
ago) I didn't lose my faith because I thought it was 'uncool' or 
'embarrassing' or because none of my friends were religious or because I 
felt excluded by the Church... I lost my faith simply because it didn't 
make sense to me, nothing added up and although I would have loved to be 
religious and would still love to be religious because it made me feel like 
I really belonged to something when I had gone through my whole life 
feeling helplessly alone, I just couldn't believe. It was never a choice to 
become an atheist, it just happened. The Church didn't need to change, it 
never did need to change, and contrary to what a lot of people think, 
teenagers don't lose faith because they are angry at God, or feel left out 
by the Church, we lose faith because it doesn't make sense. I could never 
tell how we 'knew' it all to be true, how we could take the Bible as fact 
and how we 'knew' which religion was the right one when they all seemed to 
similar yet so different. Being told to 'just believe' was never enough, 
how did I know what I should just believe?﻿

comments.text:
+ABunchOfDeadBunnies
The issue isn't, and never has been, whether or not there may or may not be 
a designer. Both Eleanor and I have stated that we are open to the 
possibility. The issue is the claim of knowledge regarding the nature of 
this designer or any claim that this designer has a substantive role in its 
creation. What's to say that the designer didn't create the earth and 
humanity and then move on to bigger and better things? Christians think 
they know, muslims think they know, hindu's think they know; atheists think 
you're all full of shit.

+Kwame Cudjoe 
You are not getting your morality from a "god" either; you're getting it 
from a book written and intended as humanity's first attempt at a civil 
system of law. Many (most) of the rules written in that book applied 
directly to the time period in which they were written (such as rules on 
rape) but are no longer applicable in today's society. BTW, morality 
existed in various forms long before the bible was ever written; it is 
responsible for human survival for the first 200,000 years on earth (just 
because the rules weren't written, doesn't mean they didn't exist). 
Further, we are not looking for "absolute morality" because the ONLY way 
for such a construct to exist would be within an extremely strict 
communistic state. As long as we enjoy freedom, absolute morality will 
never exist outside of the delusional thoughts of the religious (sorry if 
that sounds rude but please consider the premise).

+BeautyTrio
To claim to walk into buildings based upon faith illustrates a tremendous 
lack of understanding of human motivation. People inside of the WTC jumped 
to their deaths as the building behind them perished; this was not faith, 
it was a conscious decision to choose their mode of demise. You walk across 
bridges not because you have faith in the builders but because you need to 
get to the other side of the bridge. Further, I'm sorry that you CAN'T 't 
fathom existence without a creator but more sorry that you CAN fathom 
existence with one. Neither premise is within the realm of human 
understanding at this point in time thus to "buy in" to either is merely 
the byproduct of arrogance and manipulation (again, sorry to sound rude). 
There is nothing wrong with saying "I JUST DON'T FREEKIN KNOW!!!!". 
Claiming ignorance is not akin to rejection of either theory; it's an act 
of honesty and humility. 

Summary to all: Myself, and many other atheists do not reject the premise 
of a creator; we simply don't accept it based upon a lack of evidence; 
there is a difference between "not accepting as fact" and "outright 
rejecting". One is a claim of arrogant knowledge, the other is an humble 
admission of ignorance. We DO reject human claims of ownership over this 
so-called creator (religion) - in the same way that christians reject 
islam, atheists reject both. Personally, I think that if there is a heaven 
and a hell, all religious people will go to hell for being arrogant, 
elitist, separatist and hateful. Religion divides humanity into groups; 
atheists would strive to reunite us all under the loving title of "human".
comments.author: Larry L

top_comment.text:
A warning to all:
When you take off the belt of truth, stop listening to the Word of God, and 
stop reading the BIBLE, then you will delve into heresy, like Jon here. 
Jesus says in the Bible that the World hates us and thinks we are foolish 
(John 15:18-25, 1 Corinthians 1:17-25). We aren't meant to look appealing 
to them. We must preach Christ crucified, the substitution for our sins.

We come to Christ by accepting His sacrifice, praying for forgiveness of 
our sins and turning from our sin, or REPENTING. So when we evangelise to 
people, we tell them that they are made slaves to sin and need a Saviour 
who will help them out of that bondage. Without Jesus' sacrifice we will 
all perish because of sin. There are many ways to evangelise in a way that 
won't make us look like judges, but the core of true Christianity are these 
things. Not many will want to follow Jesus and would rather live in their 
sins though, which is why preachers point out that we live in a sinful 
generation and we need to help them come to know Jesus.

When Jon says we must become like the World to save the World, the 
unfortunate implication is that you will move away from God and obviously 
become like the World. You have a choice of serving two masters: God or the 
World. God promises eternal life as long as you give up your life to Him, 
but you will be the World's slave if you take on its motto: "do what you 
want". God's Word, His rules, are there to tell you that you can't do what 
you want, and they are necessary to bring someone to Christ. You cannot 
become like the World and serve God - it is impossible. Therefore, in the 
end, you will love one and hate the other (Luke 16:13).

Jesus did not go to parties to show men that they could continue in their 
licentious ways. During the marriage feast He showed His authority by 
turning water into wine to prove that He was the Son of God (John 2:11). In 
the context of making wine, it shows that the pleasurable things on the 
earth are the gift of God and we should praise Him for them. This has 
nothing to do with partying with them. Although we can still go to parties, 
we must remember to do all to the glory of God (Colossians 3:17).﻿

comments.text:
No you weren't a christian, I prayed and worshipped and didn't realize I 
wasn't saved until I actually became saved. I know you will argue with 
that, but let's agree to disagree. 

As for slavery, I'd recommend a website it's called gotquestions.org, just 
search for slavery in Old Testament, they explain it better than I could, 

Rape? God commanded rape? Sure He let it happen, but no He doesn't say Hey 
I order you to rape them. 

Genocide, God made it very clear, He told the Israelites it was not for 
anything they had done, it was only because He had let His wrath fall upon 
the wickedness of those in the lands before them. Not to mention the 400 
years He gave them to repent of their wickedness,.

yes, as for the forgiving? Is it that hard to understand why He must deal 
with sin? The most terrifying truth of God? He is good. Why is that 
terrifying? we are not. God is righteous, God is absolute holiness, and He 
cannot violate His attributes, so because of that, He cannot forgive sin. 
It must be dealt with. 

We intentionally seperated ourselves from God, an eternal defense demands 
eternal payment. If God forgave sin, would He truly be just? That is why 
the bible is totally and completely about redemption, the stories in the 
bible are just that, stories, unless you read them in their actual context, 
all pointing to Jesus. God allows what He hates to accomplish what He loves 
at some times. It wa all about what God did for us. After we offended him, 
deserving eternal punishment for our eternal offense, He created a plan to 
offer us the choice to be with Him

Jesus as God in the flesh, appeased the wrath of God, sin was dealt with on 
that tree. We aren't redeemed because the Romans naed Him to the cross, it 
was because Jesus became all sin, and God poured out His wrath and fierce 
anger against sin upon He. As it says, It pleased Yahweh to crush Him. 

I think your mistake is thinking God's intent on this earth is for us to be 
good, but It was only for us to have the choice of communion with Him. We 
either accept Him, or reject Him. Being righteous follows, but that is not 
the point. Things happened because they must, God allowed certain things 
for His redemption plan to come about As it does.

I really have to wonder the morality part, if we are nothing but primordial 
slime, and everything is subjective/determinism, I can't understand how 
someone questions God. They call The idea of Him evil, but a crime against 
humanity is only there assuming there is value to humanity, so really 
without the existence of God, you have no right to question it, and also if 
there is no God, truth as a category doesn't exist anyways, so it would be 
a lie to call a lie a lie anyways. The only value of humanity is that we 
are in the image of God, and he considered His love for us, greater than 
His majesty. He stepped off his throne to become beaten mocked and killed 
For THOSE who beat and mocked and killed Him. 

Even before I was a true christian, I knew there was a God, I didn't have 
His spirit in me like I thought I did because I didn't really get it. In 
order to understand anything of the grace of God, you have to see firsthand 
the depravity of us. 

Like I said, You would have some line to differentiate between bad and good 
to call God bad or good, without acknowledging His existence, the 
accusations self destruct. I've never struggled believing there was a God 
in general, most peoples problem with God isn't intellectual, far from it, 
it's moral. Man thinking they know better, that they shouldn't be 
accountable to anyone, as if they were Gods themselves.

Most people also make the mistake of thinking of God as just "another guy". 
Just a really powerful person. But being God, He is not anywhere close to 
what we are, as He himself says, my ways aren't your ways, my thoughts 
aren't your thoughts. He is the Judge of the Earth, all existence is rooted 
in Him, so He sets the standards of Good/Bad/justice/consequences. You 
don't have to accept Him, but you can't sneak your assumptions in, when the 
assumptions self destruct without His existence anyways. 

And by the way, I'm not trying to be mean, or condescending, or try and 
massage my ego by trying to win an internet debate, I'm really wanting to 
help. Because of course they're all existential realities we cannot run 
from, that demand explanation. I've studying studied the naturalistic 
worldview and arguments for hours upon hours and hours, and as most would 
admit, it is by no means cohearent, deism trumps naturalistic arguments, as 
God said, His glory in the universe is clearly and easily seen, atheism is 
only the result of either the inability to accept the supernatural, or as 
many former atheist will admit, the hatred of God. Science is unable to 
prove God, or disprove Him, but many atheists will only remember the prove 
part and try to make people assume the disprove part doesn't exist. However 
when it comes to at least what is more likely, and using logic and 
reasoning, it definitely supports His existence.

comments.text:
+Bryson Perry
I had the exact same experience when I let go of the fear of being atheist. 
I was sure that being a non-believer meant being a bad person so I 
struggled to believe. Finally, I had to admit that the bible does not make 
sense; talking snakes, water turning into wine, virgin births, noah's arc; 
to accept any of it requires suspension of rationality and logic - I just 
couldn't do it anymore.

Strangely, since I have admitted the truth, I have found that I speak and 
act far more like a christian than at least 95% of all christians. I am 
able to love, give and share unconditionally. I'm no longer compelled to 
threaten people with hell nor do I endeavor to promise heaven - damn, the 
shame of arrogance for ever claiming to know what happened after death and 
"to hell" with the preachers and priests who claim to know as well. They 
are liars for claiming to possess unattainable knowledge and I was equally 
guilty for spreading their lies to others.

Bryson, you want to be a good person and I admire you for it but to be 
truly good, you need to give up the lies as well. You don't know any more 
about death than I do; don't let some book or a guy in a white robe 
convince you otherwise.

of ravi zacharias videos on here, he explains morality subjective and 
objective very well. People's problem with God isn't intellectual it's 
moral, and that's because they don't understand exodus and Deuteronomy in 
it's actual full context. Generally atheists I come across have the 
thoughts they should be free to do as they please without accountability to 
anyone ultimately, and that's why they'll embrace anything not of God, 
because His existence would in their minds take that away. 

Christianity has nothing to do with feeling good, doing what makes you feel 
good, it is based off history, the resurrection of Jesus, as he claimed He 
would be resurrected, and then do that, that's entirely what it based off 
of. On paper you can talk about subjective morality, but when you look at 
reality itself, apply it to your own heart and look how Jesus described the 
human heart, His accuracy in explaining humanity is best described as 
uncanny whether you believe or not. If you don't believe, I don't see what 
your need is to try and persuade others not to think the way they do, 
considering subjective morality and thinking it's full context shows you 
have no right to, and you have nothing to base your opinions off of to 
describe whether they are right or wrong anyways

I think you are misinterpreting his use of vocabulary. He said that Jesus 
partied with sinners which he did, since the definition of party, by right 
is "a social gathering of invited guests, typically involving eating, 
drinking, and entertainment." Today, we link the term party to something 
secular. As soon as the word comes about we instinctively think of sinful 
behavior. But I don't feel like he used it in that context. I believe that 
he only used the word 'party' so that younger minds would be more open to 
the idea of Christianity. 

As for accepting gay life? I heard nothing of the sort. Please don't feel 
like I'm attacking but I feel like sharing. What I understood was that he 
meant that we should change the way we approach the one's who struggle with 
their christian lives, homosexuality, or those who just have different 
beliefs. If we try to convert them by trying to cram religion down their 
throats instead of trying to understand why they haven't gotten it 
themselves, we might just be losing souls. The way we approach people, 
especially non-Christians matter. We have to set an example for them and 
show them that this live isn't as bad as it's made out to be. We have to 
let them know that its okay to trust the people of God, and in time, become 
one. 

We as the older generation should've seen past the words of this video and 
listened to the message, which was a pretty powerful and factual one if you 
ask me.

top_comment.text:
Types of Christians:

Sunday Only: Those who practice the beliefs and precepts of Christianity on 
Sunday and act differently the 6 other days of the week.

Motions Only: Those who attend church but are disconnected and not paying 
attention. They sit in church just so they appear normal. Appearing normal 
is the same as conformity to societies ways.

Pick and Choose: The practitioners that choose only to believe in some of 
the ideals as laid out according to the Bible, while dismissing other 
ideals as wrong or untruthful.

Greed Only: People who claim to be Christian yet their actions demonstrate 
only greed. Greed not only to monetary resources but greed to all 
resources. The ones who take more than their fair share of gifts we all 
need to survive.

My Way or Highway: These are the Christians that truthfully believe that 
their ideals and values are the only ones worthy to God. This group isn't 
inherently evil but when taken to the extreme results in bigotry.

Everyday: Those Christians who in general follow the path that Jesus wanted 
them to follow. They try their best to be righteous with sincerity yet they 
also realize that as humans they make mistakes and break the laws of God. 
While they may sin they actively seek to be forgiven and try better in the 
future.

Altruistic: These are the followers that respect others yet follow the path 
Jesus wanted to follow. They follow this path everyday and rarely sin.. 
They are inherently givers and not takers. As a giver they respect everyone 
no matter their belief system.﻿

captions.text:
So to get right to the point today, I got
a little game that I'd like for y'all to play.

It's called "How many teenagers do you know
that are actively pursuing a life with God?"

For most of us, that game doesn't last very
long. Like a bangin' on a gong, the preachers

say, "What's wrong with kids today?" and the
song goes on and on and on. But the song being

sung is partly true. We're surrounded by a
generation who, for the most part, would rather

smoke a joint than sit in a pew, and to be
honest, I'm really tired of placing all the

blame on them. So I'm here to suggest that
perhaps part of the problem, church, is you.

Please hear me out. You see, teenagers today,
and people, for that matter, would rather

live by their own luck because they see the
religious system is just way too stuck, and

if you heard me say that I read my Bible every
day, you'd be like "What the fudge? Doesn't

that mean you're quick to judge, never budge,
and just a plain old schmuck?" And if this

is the perception that we're so full of pride,
then perhaps it's time we took a look inside

and tried to reclaim the part of Jesus that
some of us have lost: the one who partied

with sinners, touched the lepers, loved the
children, and who paid the highest cost.

Have you ever considered just how many parties
Jesus went to in the Gospels? If someone wanted

to throw a party today, church, I'm not sure
that they would hire us. People don't wanna

gather around Jesus anymore. They gather around
Lady Gaga and Miley Cyrus. And I'm not here

to bash secular music, either. I'm tired of
that, and plus, I like some of those songs.

I'm here to suggest, church, that we also
might be in the wrong.

Please hear me out. You see, it's clear in
the lives of the next generation, the church

rarely plays a part, and maybe that's because
some of the messages in TV, and film, and

radio are a little bit more from the heart.
The church shouldn't be this billboard of

propaganda, a list of shoulds and should nots.
It should be a living, breathing artpiece,

where people see us, and they say, "I want
what they've got!" When did the movement of

Jesus lose its authenticity and require its
members to climb to some spiritual peak? Because

if only the strong survive, then how come
His power is perfect when we're weak?

Now please, hear me. I know some churches
do this right, and I'm not tryin' to start

a fight. I'm here to suggest that we might
just be as blind as those to whom we're trying

to give sight. We as the church need to wisen
up because the next generation is rising up,

and they're finding their prize in the things
of this world because in their eyes, we haven't

given them a better option. Runnin' away from
the church like a toxin, because some of us

are locked into a system of judgment and dismay,
hate you if you're struggling, different,

or gay. Why would anyone want to stay when
they're just viewed as a project on which

we can project a list of rules? And the more
we try and protect the children in this way,

the more we reject what God is trying to project
through them! And that is His project of
authentic love.

Please hear me out. You've made it this far.
I'm not trying to be harsh, and I'm not trying

to be condemning to either side. I'm suggesting
that instead of forcing people onto some religious

journey, let's just invite them along for
the ride. Let's look to share, before we look

to teach, and maybe let's put a little more
care into what we preach. Let us make faith

in Jesus a little more attractive, and by
that, I'm not talking about hip, or cool.

I'm talking about interactive - because you
can never underestimate the power of someone

who truly cares and who dares to be the one
person who will listen when no one else will.

This is the kind of love that I believe Jesus
was talking about, that authentic love that

spurs us to a life that people can't help
but be attracted to.

Church, let us begin to live in that love.
And let us stop blaming the younger generation

for every problem in the world, and instead,
come alongside them and invite them on an

adventure that Jesus said would bring even
greater things yet to come.
This is authentic love.

title: A "Godless" Generation - Jon Jorgenson | Spoken Word
